contextId.occurrenceNote: The sight of Yahweh represents his judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: "as Yahweh judged" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person telling others about something that has happened is spoken of as if the person were carrying a solid object and giving it to those other people. Alternate translation: "to tell what had happened" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to carry the news

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here ruling over the people is spoken of as shepherding them. Alternate translation: "'You will care for my people Israel" or "You will lead my people Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You will shepherd my people Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of the water as if it were blood because the men risked their lives to bring the water to him. He uses a question to emphasize this. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "I should not drink this water, which would be like drinking the blood of these men who have risked their lives to bring it to me." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Should I drink the blood of these men who have risked their lives?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Spirit empowering Amasai is spoken of as if the Spirit came on him. Alternate translation: "the Spirit empowered Amasai" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the Spirit came on Amasai

contextId.occurrenceNote: The men making David king in place of Saul is spoken of as if they gave possession of Saul's kingdom to David. Alternate translation: "to make David king in place of Saul" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to turn the kingdom of Saul over to him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "eyes" represents seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: "all the people considered these things to be right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they seemed right in the eyes of all the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's anger is spoken of as if it were a fire that burned the one with whom Yahweh is angry. Alternate translation: "Yahweh was very angry with Uzzah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the anger of Yahweh burned against Uzzah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the sound of the leaves rustling as wind blows through them as if it were the sound of marching. Alternate translation: "When the wind blowing through the tops of the balsam trees sounds like men marching" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: When you hear the sound of marching in the wind blowing through the balsam treetops

contextId.occurrenceNote: Those who are leaders of the people of Israel are spoken of as if they were shepherds and the people were sheep. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: whom I appointed to shepherd my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh destroying David's enemies is spoken of as if Yahweh cut them off, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: cut off all your enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: God causing the people to live in the land permanently and securely is spoken of as if he would plant them in the land. Alternate translation: "I will settle them there" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will plant them there

contextId.occurrenceNote: God appointing David's descendant is spoken of as if Yahweh would raise or lift him up. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will raise up your descendant after you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: "in your judgment" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in your sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks about time as if it were something that travels and arrives somewhere. Alternate translation: "and what will happen to them in the future" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for a great while to come

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "stench" refers to a bad smell. This describes the Ammonites as something unpleasant and unwanted. Alternate translation: "realized that they had become repulsive to David" or "realized that they had angered David" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: saw that they had become a stench to David

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: "what he considers to be good" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: what is good in his eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of the people of Israel as if they were sheep, who are known for trusting and following their leader. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: But these sheep

contextId.occurrenceNote: God will treat Solomon as if he were God's own son. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He will be my son, and I will be his father

contextId.occurrenceNote: Seeking Yahweh represents either 1) asking God for help or 2) thinking about God and obeying him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: seek Yahweh your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heads" is a metaphor for the more important people—the leaders of the clans. Alternate translation: "leaders of the clans" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: heads of clans

contextId.occurrenceNote: An animal horn is a symbol of strength or authority. To lift up someone's horn is a metaphor for honoring him. Alternate translation: "to honor Heman" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to lift up his horn

contextId.occurrenceNote: This does not mean that Solomon becomes an actual son of God, but it describes the personal relationship that he and God will have. Alternate translation: "I have chosen to treat him like a son, and I will be like a father to him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have chosen him to be my son, and I will be his father

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh having control over whether people are powerful or not as if "power and might" were something in hand that he had control over. Alternate translation: "You determine who has power and might" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: In your hand is power and might

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of people's lives being short as if they were travelers only here on earth for a short time. Alternate translation: "For our lives are short and we are like strangers and travelers who pass before you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: we are strangers and travelers before you
